title: A Quick Guide to Corn Harvesting

steps.title: Harvest sweet corn 60-80 days after planting it.
steps.content: Harvest sweet corn 60-80 days after planting it. On average, sweet corn takes 60-80 days to mature. Make a note on your calendar to check for harvesting signs at around 60 days after planting. [1] X Research source Corn harvests quickest in hot weather, especially temperatures over 90 째F (32 째C). [2] X Research source

steps.title: Harvest the corn when the tassels turn brown.
steps.content: Harvest the corn when the tassels turn brown. The corn tassel is the pollen-releasing stem on the tops of corn plants. As your corn matures, its tassels should turn from green to brown. Avoid harvesting the corn until the tassels' green color has disappeared completely. [3] X Research source The tassels should turn brown about 3 weeks after the plant flowers. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Squeeze sweet corn kernels to check for a milky fluid.
steps.content: Squeeze sweet corn kernels to check for a milky fluid. Pull back the corn silk and squeeze a kernel between your finger and thumb. If the kernel releases a milky fluid, your plant is ready for harvest. [5] X Research source If your corn kernels are not mature, they will be firm and won't release a milky fluid. If that's the case, smooth the silk and husk back over unripe kernels. Your corn will still mature without any problems. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Twist each corn ear off of its stalk.
steps.content: Twist each corn ear off of its stalk. Hold the stalk in your non-dominant hand to steady it while you harvest. With your dominant hand, grab a corn ear and twist it to the side. Pull the ear down and yank hard, then put your freshly-picked corn in a bucket or pile. [7] X Research source Pulling on the cornstalk without twisting can kill the plant. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Prepare sweet corn quickly to prevent the flavor from deteriorating.
steps.content: Prepare sweet corn quickly to prevent the flavor from deteriorating. When left in room-temperature conditions for 24 hours, sweet corn loses 50% of its sugar. Store or prepare sweet corn the same day that you pick it for a fresher taste. [9] X Research source You can store sweet corn in the fridge for 2-4 days by wrapping unopened husks in damp paper towels. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Remove
steps.content: Remove the corn husk and silk. Pull on the husk leaves one at a time until you have completely exposed the small silky hairs covering the kernels. Pick off the silk one hair at a time or use an old toothbrush to rub them off. [11] X Research source Microwaving the corn can make it easier to husk. Set the microwave power to high and heat the unhusked corn for 2 minutes. Put the silk and husks in a large container or trash bag to make cleanup easier.

steps.title: Freeze
steps.content: Freeze sweet corn to preserve it for 6-8 months. Blanch your corn in boiling water, then put your corn cobs in an airtight container and store it in the freezer. Freeze your corn for up to 6-8 months to have fresh-tasting corn no matter the season. [12] X Research source You can also cut the kernels off of the cob with a knife before freezing for compact storage.

steps.title: Can
steps.content: Can sweet corn to preserve it for up to 5 years. If you don't plan on cooking your corn 2-4 days after harvesting, blanch your corn and remove the kernels with a sharp knife. Store the kernels in a jar and place them in a pressure canner to seal the jar. [13] X Research source Canned corn tends to last longer than frozen corn at around 3-5 years. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Cook sweet corn as a side dish if you want to eat it right away.
steps.content: Cook sweet corn as a side dish if you want to eat it right away. Sweet corn makes a healthy, delicious side for most meals. You can cook fresh or preserved corn by boiling, microwaving, baking, grilling, or steaming it. [15] X Research source If you do not want to store your sweet corn, cook it immediately after harvesting. [16] X Trustworthy Source Michigan State University Extension Extension program of Michigan State University focused on community outreach, education, and engagement Go to source

steps.title: Plan to harvest flint corn 80-100 days after planting it.
steps.content: Plan to harvest flint corn 80-100 days after planting it. Unlike sweet corn, flint corn takes between 80-100 days to harvest. After 80 days have passed since planting, check your flint corn every day for signs of maturity. [17] X Research source Corn harvests faster in temperatures over 90 째F (32 째C). If you live in a warm climate, your flint corn will mature closer to 80 days. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Check the corn tassels for a brown color.
steps.content: Check the corn tassels for a brown color. Corn tassels are the pollen-releasing stems on the tops of the plant. As your corn matures, its tassels should change colors from green to brown. Wait until tassels' green color has disappeared completely to harvest your corn. [19] X Research source Corn tassels, on average, turn brown around 3 weeks after the plant flowers. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Wait until flint corn kernels are firm.
steps.content: Wait until flint corn kernels are firm. Flint corn and popcorn kernels should be dry and firm. Press on a corn kernel between your finger and thumb and, if it feels hardened, pick it as long as the tassels are brown and 80 days have passed since planting. [21] X Research source If the corn kernels aren't quite matured, smooth the silk and husk back over. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the corn from its stalk.
steps.content: Pull the corn from its stalk. Hold the stalk in your non-dominant hand to steady it and, with your dominant hand, twist the ear once to the side. Pull the ear downward and yank it off of the stalk, placing your freshly-picked corn in a bucket or pile. [23] X Research source Pulling on the cornstalk without twisting can kill the plant. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Hang flint and popcorn cobs up to dry for 2-3 weeks.
steps.content: Hang flint and popcorn cobs up to dry for 2-3 weeks. Find an empty indoor space, like a garage or storage shed, to store your corn. Tie a length of twine around each corn cob and hang them from the ceiling or rafters. Let them hang for about 2-3 weeks, then transfer them to a dry container like a bucket or a storage bin. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Grind flint corn or use it as livestock feed.
steps.content: Grind flint corn or use it as livestock feed. If you have a corn mill or a high-powered blender, you can use your flint corn for cornmeal. Otherwise, flint corn can make a cheap feed for livestock. [26] X Research source Cornmeal is a healthy, filling flour that you can use for cornbread, polenta, tamales, and other dishes. [27] X Research source You can also use flint corn as an autumn decoration.

steps.title: Rub off popcorn kernels and store them.
steps.content: Rub off popcorn kernels and store them. After drying your popcorn cob, pull the kernels off with your hand or cut them off with a knife. Store them in a dry, airtight container until you're ready to cook with them. [28] X Research source Although popcorn is a type of flint corn, it is the only corn variety that pops when you heat it. Do not try making popcorn from other varieties.

steps.title: Heat popcorn kernels
steps.content: Heat popcorn kernels to cook them. Depending on your preferences, you can microwave popcorn or heat it over a stove top. Keep the kernels under constant heat until they pop into light, fluffy popped corn.

steps.title: Grind popcorn into cornmeal as an alternative to popping.
steps.content: Grind popcorn into cornmeal as an alternative to popping. Like other flint corn varieties, you can grind popcorn into corn meal. If you want to use popcorn for baking, grind it using a high-powered blender or a corn mill. You can also use popcorn as livestock feed, if preferred.
